text: Morning mist rolled down from the distant hills, spreading along the stone-paved streets into the heart of the town. The air inside the inn carried a faint scent of ash and wood.
I stood behind the counter, polishing a glass. The view outside was blurred by fog, and the hanging lamps swayed gently overhead.
This was the most ordinary moment of the day—before the travelers arrived, when only the echo of glass and the rhythm of my own breathing filled the room.
Sometimes I even wondered if I existed for this moment alone: the stillness before the world awoke, when time itself seemed to show a trace of mercy.
But that morning was different.
The door burst open with a crash. A rush of cold air flooded in, carrying the scent of snow and iron. The wooden door slammed against the wall, shattering the tavern’s calm.
“Your wine any good here? Get me a bottle—make it quick!”
He wore grimy leather armor, a broken mercenary badge hanging around his neck. He looked like he’d crawled straight out of a ruin.
“Drinking already? The town guards will be here soon. I thought they didn’t allow you to drink on duty.”
“Another bottle! Or I’ll burn this lousy tavern down with me!”
His eyes were murky, like greasy water. The stench of decay and gunpowder clung to him, sharp and heavy.
A few guests shrank back into the corners. Before I could respond, the sound of steady footsteps came from outside.
“I heard someone was threatening to burn a place down.” A woman’s voice rang out—clear, crisp, like snow falling onto steel.
A woman in a silver-white cloak stepped inside. Sunlight followed her through the doorway, glinting off the faint polish of her armor.
She was tall, her sword sheath etched with intricate patterns. A weathered lily emblem rested on her shoulder plate.
Her gaze was calm, yet something about it made approach impossible.
“Good morning.”
Her voice was bright—without force, yet enough to quiet the room.
She walked toward the drunkard, step by step. He froze for a second, then snarled, “Get lost! Mind your own damn business—”
Before he could finish, she lifted a hand and drew a line through the air. The wind stilled. The bottle flew from his grasp and landed softly in her palm.
In that instant, the entire tavern seemed frozen in place. Even the fire in the hearth flickered uncertainly.

options.text: Option A: Step forward and try to calm him down [Charisma Check DC 4]
Option B: Stay still and observe the situation [No Check DC 0]
Option C: Quietly ready your short sword [Strength Check DC 6]
